Description: Hollow terracotta figure of Bes standing, naked and armed, with sword held high and a circular shield on his left arm. He wears a feathered crown. Traces of a white coating and red paint on the skin and green/blue (?) on the headdress. Two-piece mould, hollow, with a plain back. Red-brown Nile silt with mica.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallel from the British Museum, dated to the third or second century BC (Bailey 2008, 3095; EA 1926,0520.14). Parallels from Bubastis (Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, no. 1881.57; Hilton Price 1897, 394, no. 3269), Hermopolis Magna (Roeder 1937, pl. 13c) dated late second and first century BC (Török 1995, no. 16) and unprovenanced (Breccia 1934, no. 189; Ewigleben and von Grumbkow 1991, no. 51; Ghalioungui and Wagner 1974, pl. 61e). Breccia, E. 1934, Monuments de l’Égypte gréco-romaine II. Terrecotte figurate greche e greco-egizie del Museo di Alessandria, 2, Bergamo. Hilton Price, F. G. 1897, A Catalogue of the Egyptian Antiquities, London. Török, L. 1995. ‘Hellenistic and Roman terracottas from Egypt’. Rome von Bissing, F.W. 1931. In ‘Zeitschrift für Ägyptische Sprache und Altertumskunde’ 67.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.207) (Phase 3)
